In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  proposed  policy  and  advisory  technical  assistance  (TA)  will  support  strategic 
planning  and  policy  development,  better  management  guidelines,  and  targeted  associated 
capacity development in the water resources sector in Indonesia.1 To support development of 
the water sector (both water resources and water supply and sanitation) in Indonesia, the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) established in 2010 a water team within the Indonesia Resident 
Mission in Jakarta to provide strategic guidance and policy support to the Government of 
Indonesia, and to help coordinate and develop ADB’s water program. The TA is in response to 
ongoing dialogue between the resident mission and the government, and the government’s 
expressed need for assistance to address key policy issues in the water resources sector and to 
strengthen water resources management in Indonesia. 
 
2.  A fact-finding mission was undertaken from 20 July to 4 August 2010 (intermittent) that (i) 
shared the concept paper with the government; (ii) defined the policy areas and scope of work 
for the TA based on earlier dialogue with the government; (iii) confirmed the TA’s impact and 
outcome, outline terms of reference, costs and financing, and implementation arrangements; (iv) 
verified that the TA was in the “Blue Book” programs list for Bappenas, the State Ministry of 
Development and Planning; and (v) met with the Embassy of Japan to discuss the TA. Concept 
clearance for the TA was approved on 16 August 2010. The design and monitoring framework is 
in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Although progress has been made with regard to institutional reform in Indonesia’s water 
resources sector, including passage of the national Water Law in 2004, the sector is facing 
critical  challenges  as  the  government  seeks  to  manage  water  resources  and  develop 
infrastructure in a sustainable manner. In framing the Water Law, the government adopted the 
principles  of  integrated  water  resources  management  (IWRM)  to  guide  it,  but  work  is  still 
needed to develop the specific policies, rules, and regulations to implement the law. Indonesia 
has undergone an extensive decentralization process over the last decade, and it still needs to 
clarify the roles of central, provincial, and district governments in the water resources sector to 
ensure more effective management and development. The TA will focus primarily on improving 
the  institutional  arrangements  for  (i)  integrated  water  resources  management—river  basin 
management, in particular; and (ii) irrigation management and development. 
 
4.  River basin organizations and water resources management. In line with the IWRM 
principles, the government has restructured the institutional arrangements for water resources 
management  through  the  creation  of  river  basin  organizations  (RBOs)  under  the  central 
government.  For  strategic  basins  and  basins  that  cross  provincial  boundaries,  the  central 
government has assumed overall water management responsibility. At the same time, provincial 
authorities still perform most operation and maintenance (O&M) and management functions, 
sometimes  according  to  short-term  role-sharing  agreements.  Greater  clarity  is  needed  in 
defining the water management roles and responsibilities of the RBOs, and the long-term 
development activities to be undertaken by the central, provincial, and district water agencies. 
ADB’s  experience  with  the  Integrated  Citarum  Water  Resources  Management  Investment 
Program,2 periodic financing request 1, and the TA for Capacity Building in Water Resources in

a Decentralized Environment3 have also helped recognize the need for further reform and 
greater clarity of institutional responsibilities among various agencies. The government has 
formed strategic basins to be managed centrally under the Water Law and would like overall 
policy guidance regarding this approach, which is based in part on the Citarum experience. 
Financing the development, operation and maintenance (O&M), and management of water 
resources  and  associated  infrastructure  requires  greater  cooperation  between  government 
agencies and clearly defined responsibilities, in particular regarding the flow and management 
of funds. In some cases where the central government has assumed control of the management 
of a river basin, the provincial and district governments have stopped providing resources 
needed to manage and develop water resources. There is a need for stronger cooperation and 
coordination mechanisms between the various levels of government in allocating resources for 
O&M and to manage and develop projects. 
 
5.  Irrigation management and development. Irrigation accounts for nearly 80% of the 
use of all developed water resources in Indonesia and is critical for (i) the government’s strategy 
for food security, which relies on self-sufficiency for rice production; (ii) development of the rural 
economy; and (iii) poverty reduction. ADB’s Participatory Irrigation Sector Project4 (PISP) is 
ongoing and, along with the World Bank’s Water Resources and Irrigation Sector Management 
Program  (WRISMP),  provides  rehabilitation,  capacity  development,  and  institutional 
strengthening for irrigation. Both PISP and WRISMP support the formation of water users’ 
associations (WUAs) to encourage farmers to take a more active role in operating, maintaining, 
and  managing  irrigation  service  delivery.  While  these  WUAs  participate  in  the  externally 
financed donor programs, their long-term role in the irrigation sector throughout Indonesia 
needs to be developed. 
 
6.  Similar  to  the  problems  with  RBOs  and  water  resources  management,  irrigation 
management suffers from an overlap of functions and a lack of clarity in the responsibilities of 
central, provincial, and district governments, as well as uncertainty over the roles of WUAs. 
According to current regulations, the central government is responsible for schemes of more 
than 3,000 hectares (ha), the provincial governments for schemes from 1,000 ha to 3,000 ha, 
and district governments for schemes of less than 1,000 ha. However, the capacity of the 
various agencies at different levels of government varies tremendously and in some cases, 
management arrangements for irrigation are based on short-term role-sharing agreements and 
may  be  unclear.  At  present,  the  flow  of  funds  between  the  central,  provincial  and  district 
governments for O&M of the irrigation schemes is not sufficiently coordinated to ensure the 
highest possible or sustainable productivity. Under the PISP and WRISMP, memorandums of 
understanding  (MOUs)  are  being  pursued  between  WUAs,  and  district  and  provincial 
governments  to  improve  O&M  and  fund  flows.  However,  in  the  long  term,  institutional 
restructuring may be the more robust solution. All these issues have been flagged as areas that 
need reform through ADB’s experience with PISP. 
 
7.  In  addition  to  O&M  and  management  of  the  existing  irrigation  schemes,  significant 
investment  is  needed  to  advance  the  irrigation  sector,  including  the  development  of  new 
irrigation  schemes.  The  rapidly  growing  population,  the  government’s  commitment  to  food 
security through self-sufficiency in rice production, and the significant conversion of agricultural 
land—especially  in  Java,  which  has  the  greatest  productivity  per  hectare—necessitate  the

expansion of irrigated agriculture in new areas. The uncertainty of climate change and its 
impacts on food production, and the need for long-term resilience of irrigated agriculture also 
require  planning  and  investment.  The  government  has  committed  to  the  development  of 
500,000 ha of new irrigation schemes throughout Indonesia. However, it does not have a fully 
developed plan for prioritizing, selecting, and financing the schemes. Assistance is needed to 
help shape a strategic vision for the future of irrigation and a plan to achieve it. 
 
8.  ADB and the government program. The country strategy and program, 2006–2009 
and the new country partnership strategy (to be approved in 2011) call for more infrastructure 
investment and stronger natural resources management, and the water resources sector plays 
a primary role in ADB’s portfolio.5 ADB’s 2010 country operations business plan for Indonesia 
includes over $1 billion of ongoing and planned investment in the water resources sector.6 
Development  of  water  resources infrastructure  is  a  core  activity  in  ADB’s  Strategy  2020.7 
Development of water resources infrastructure, particularly irrigation, is also a key priority of the 
government’s  National  Medium-Term  Plan,  2010–2014.  The  TA  is  consistent  with  ongoing 
programs of the government and the Directorate General of Water Resources (DGWR) to build 
capacity and develop the water resources sector, especially river basin management. The 
scope of the proposed TA is based on the experience and lessons learned from implementing 
ADB’s program for water resources in Indonesia under the Integrated Citarum Water Resources 
Management  Investment  Program,  PISP,  and  Capacity  Building  in  Water  Resources  in  a 
Decentralized Environment. The TA is coordinated with and complements ongoing projects by 
ADB’s  development  partners,  including  the  Government  of  the  Netherlands,  the  Japan 
International Cooperation Agency, and the World Bank. The TA will contribute strongly to ADB’s 
forward program in the sector. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
9.  The impact of the TA will be improved management and development of the water 
resources sector. The outcome of the TA will be a stronger institutional framework for the water 
resources sector. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
10.  The TA will have three outputs: (i) RBOs and water resources management, (ii) irrigation 
management and development, and (iii) dissemination and capacity development. The first two 
outputs comprise the analytical and technical work that will be carried out under the TA. The 
analytical methodology will involve two approaches. First, there will be extensive consultations 
with key stakeholders and a review of laws, policies, and regulations to assess how the roles 
and responsibilities are defined within and shared between the central, provincial, and district 
agencies, and how best to promote a comprehensive water management approach in place of a 
relatively  exclusive  focus  on  construction  and  rehabilitation.  The  TA  will  assess  gaps  and 
constraints in existing policies, rules, and regulations that impede effective management and 
development of water resources. The analysis will include an evaluation of current budgeting, 
planning, and investment processes for water resources and irrigation infrastructure at the 
district, provincial, river basin and central levels. The second approach will be applied analysis

using selective case studies. In consultation with the government, at least two basins for the 
RBO output and at least two basins and/or provinces for the irrigation output will be selected for 
practical  analysis.  The  TA  will  look  at  the  prevailing  realities  for  RBOs  and  irrigation 
management  to  assess  current  practices  and  the  capacity  for  O&M,  management,  and 
development of water resources and irrigation. Based on the analytical work, the TA will make 
recommendations for stronger coordination and management. The ultimate goal of the TA is to 
pilot-test  these  recommended  institutional  improvements  with  a  view  towards  eventual 
mainstreaming. 
 
11.  Output 1 of the TA—RBOs and water resources management—will recommend ways to 
improve the institutional framework, clarify the roles and responsibilities (policies, rules, and 
regulations) and the flow of funds for more effective management and development of the water 
resources sector, along with developing tools (e.g., MOUs and role-sharing agreements) for 
better  cooperation  in  allocating  resources.  This  output  will  result  in  revised  institutional 
arrangements and policy improvements that will be implemented by the government in selected 
river basins on a pilot basis, focused on the specific needs of the pilot basins. Output 2—
irrigation management and development—will recommend measures to improve the institutional 
framework, clarify the roles and responsibilities (policies, rules, and regulations) and the flow of 
funds, along with developing tools (such as MOUs and role-sharing agreements) for better 
cooperation and more effective management and development of irrigation in Indonesia. This 
output will result in revised institutional arrangements and policy improvements that will be 
implemented  on  a  pilot  basis.  The  outputs  will  include  policy  and  strategy  documents, 
recommended  rules  and  regulations,  and  stronger  coordination  mechanisms  to  strengthen 
water resources management and irrigation. 
 
12.  In addition, output 2 will undertake detailed analysis of the irrigation subsector in light of 
future irrigation needs for Indonesia, taking into account issues such as climate change and 
food  security.  The  analysis  will  identify  the  factors  and  constraints  affecting  irrigation 
development in the short, medium, and long term. Based on this analysis, the TA will develop 
criteria, methodologies, and institutional processes for investment planning in the irrigation 
subsector within a decentralized context. The TA will also evaluate the financial needs for 
expanding the irrigation subsector in line with the proposed strategy developed through the TA. 
 
13.  Output 3—dissemination and capacity development—will be cross-cutting for the first 
two outputs. TA outputs, policy recommendations, and lessons learned will be disseminated 
through  (i)  workshops,  focus  groups,  and  conferences;  (ii)  consultations  with  development 
partners and civil society; (iii) ADB's water community of practice; and (iv) publication of at least 
one knowledge product. Since adoption of the policy recommendations is a key objective of the 
TA,  effective  dissemination  and  awareness  raising  among  stakeholders  is  most  important. 
Limited targeted capacity development activities, and training directly related to TA outputs and 
outcomes will be provided to government staff and other stakeholders. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
14.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $550,000 equivalent, of which $500,000 will be 
financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction, and administered by ADB.  
The government of Indonesia will contribute the remaining $50,000 equivalent in kind. Details of 
the cost estimates and financing are in Appendix 2.

5
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
15.  Bappenas will be the executing agency and the Directorate General of Water Resources 
(DGWR) within the Ministry of Public Works will be the implementing agency. It was agreed 
between Bappenas and DGWR that Bappenas would be the executing agency because it has a 
broader sector view for water resources than DGWR. Bappenas is also responsible for planning 
and policy development and thus more suited to lead the TA. Policy guidance and final review of 
TA outputs rests with the director for water resources and irrigation at Bappenas in consultation 
with the director general at DGWR. DGWR will be the primary agency to coordinate TA activities 
and provide support in the field. The TA will also work closely with the Ministry of Agriculture for 
the irrigation activities, particularly for the draft irrigation strategy that will require policy analysis 
and other inputs by the agricultural sector. Other related agencies such as the Ministry of 
Environment will be consulted, and central, provincial and district stakeholders will be engaged 
in all activities, particularly in the case study areas. 
 
16.  The TA will require about 40 person-months of consulting services—12 international and 
28 national person-months—over an implementation period of 14 months, plus 3 months for TA 
closing. It is anticipated that the TA will start in February 2011 and will finish by April 2012. 
Consultants  with  specialization  in  IWRM  and  irrigation  will  be  recruited  as  individuals.  All 
consultants will be selected in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants 
(2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time.  The  terms  of  reference  for  the  consultants  are  in 
Appendix 3. Any procurement under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB's Procurement 
Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). Equipment for the TA will be procured by the 
TA  consultants  and  turned  over  to  the  government  upon  completion  of  the  TA.  All 
disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
 
17.  The  Indonesia  Resident  Mission  will  administer  the  TA,  ensuring  continuous 
communication  and  monitoring  of  progress.  Since  the  TA  will  cover  policy  and  strategy 
formulation, effective policy dialogue is essential. The TA is designed to provide a platform for 
dialogue and advisory services by the resident mission’s water team, and the project officer(s) 
will participate in frequent meetings with the government to discuss progress and application of 
TA outputs. Inception reports will be prepared and discussed with the government to finalize the 
terms of reference and confirm specific policy issues to be addressed during the TA. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of Indonesia to be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction for 
Institutional Strengthening for the Water Resources Sector, and hereby reports this action to the 
Board.

10  Appendix 3   
 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The  following  terms  of  reference  are  for  the  two  main  thematic  areas  (or  outputs) 
covered  by  the  technical  assistance  (TA):  (i)  river  basin  organizations  (RBOs)  and  water 
resources  management,  and  (ii)  irrigation  management  and  development.  The  terms  of 
reference define the tasks to be undertaken by the international specialists each with support 
from two national specialists. One of the national specialists would be a more junior person who 
would assist the team’s activities and execute technically less challenging tasks. The other 
national specialist would be a senior specialist, and expected to be the team leader of his or her 
thematic  area,  coordinate  all  the  activities  within  the  output  (including  administration),  and 
contribute significantly to the TA and its outputs. At present, the terms of reference are not 
separated into specific tasks for the national and international specialists. They will be revised 
after further discussion during inception. 
 
2.  Water resources management specialists (6 person-months of international and 
14 person-months of national input). The water resources management specialists will have 
experience working with RBOs, preferably in an applied and operational setting, and be familiar 
with the principles of integrated water resources management (IWRM). The international and 
senior  national  specialists  should have  an  advanced  degree  in  a  subject  related  to  water 
resources and at least 10 years of relevant experience. The specialists should have strong 
interpersonal and communication skills, be fluent in written and spoken English, and have 
proven ability in report writing for professional purposes. 
 
(i)  With the executing and implementing agencies, select a sample of representative 
basins to evaluate the institutional arrangements that guide role sharing among 
central, provincial and district governments in water resources management. This 
should include the six Cis river basin territory that is currently a part of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) TA.1 
(ii)  Compile existing reviews of and provide additional comments on the 2004 Water 
Law,  related  policy  documents,  and  implementing  rules  and  regulations 
governing water resources management, particularly the role of RBOs and basin 
management. This should also include a review of the role of basin councils, 
provincial  water  councils,  the  national  water  council,  and  other  civic  bodies 
involved in water resources and basin management. 
(iii)  Review  the  law,  latest  regulations,  and  current  practices  regarding 
decentralization,  with  a  focus  on  provincial  and  district  agencies’  roles  and 
responsibilities for water resources management. 
(iv)  Assess the policy that governs the designation of strategic basins that fall under 
central government control. 
(v)  Examine government procedures for fund allocation to support water resources 
management by central, provincial, and district agencies, and their adequacy. 
Assess  the  implication  of  centrally  administered  basins  on  the  allocation  of 
provincial and district financing, and support for water resources management, 
especially operation and maintenance (O&M). 
(vi)  Review  options  and  make  recommendations  to  improve  the  institutional 
effectiveness of management within, and cooperation and fund flows among 
central, provincial, and district agencies. Develop options for mechanisms such

Management in the 6 Cis River Basin Territory. Manila (TA 7189-INO). The 6 Cis include the Citarum River and 
five neighboring basins that have been combined into one strategic national basin.

Appendix 3  11 
as memorandums of understanding or other role-sharing agreements to improve 
cooperation  and  management  effectiveness,  and  make  recommendations 
regarding the authority to enter these agreements and the structure of such 
agreements. 
(vii)  Review the capacity and staff requirements for basin management, taking into 
account the different levels of government and their implication for management 
and capacity development. 
(viii)  Assess current responsibilities for data collection and management, and sharing 
arrangements  among  central,  provincial,  and  district  governments.  Identify 
constraints  and  bottlenecks,  and  recommend  measures  to  improve  data 
collection, management, and sharing of information. 
(ix)  Examine  current  roles  and  processes  for  water  allocation  and  water-use 
monitoring within basins (focus on surface water). Make recommendations to 
clarify roles and responsibilities in different agencies. 
(x)  Assess current mechanisms for solving conflicts over water resources under 
existing  national,  provincial,  and  district  institutional  arrangements.  Make 
recommendations to improve the conflict resolution mechanisms.  
(xi)  Assist the Directorate General of Water Resources in specifying basins that face 
critical  water  management  issues  and  make  recommendations  on  suitable 
institutional arrangements for current and future management. 
(xii)  Arrange a workshop to vet and discuss TA findings and outputs, and prepare 
follow-up actions.  
(xiii)  Prepare policies, guidelines, rules, and regulations as required to implement TA 
findings, and develop an action plan for their adoption. 
(xiv)  Disseminate outputs and support implementation of TA recommendations and 
guidelines on a pilot or permanent basis.  
(xv)  Define  training  needs,  prepare  targeted  capacity  development  activities  as 
required, and pinpoint events for participation by government officials.  
 
3.  Irrigation  management  specialists  (6  person-months  of  international  and  14 
person-months of national input). The irrigation management specialists will have experience 
in managing and developing large and small gravity irrigation schemes, and be familiar with 
IWRM principles. The international and senior national specialists should have an advanced 
degree  in  a  subject  relevant  to  irrigation  management  and  at  least  10  years  of  related 
experience. The specialists should have strong interpersonal and communication skills, be 
fluent in written and spoken English, and have proven ability in report writing for professional 
purposes. 
 
(i)  With the executing and implementing agencies, select a sample of provinces 
where  irrigation  management  and  development  is  hampered  by  inefficient 
sharing  of  roles  and  responsibilities  among  central,  provincial,  and  district 
agencies. 
(ii)  Review lessons learned from ADB’s Participatory Irrigation Sector Project (PISP) 
and  the  World  Bank’s  Water  Resources  and  Irrigation  Sector  Management 
Project,  and  their  application  to  role  sharing  and  water  users’  associations 
(WUAs) in irrigation management. 
(iii)  Assess the policies and guidelines on irrigation, particularly those concerning the 
sharing  of  roles  between  central,  provincial,  and  district  authorities  in  O&M, 
management, and development of irrigation systems, and how this sharing is 
being exercised in practice. Identify constraints, areas of uncertainty, and other 
problems with current role sharing.

12  Appendix 3 
(iv)  Specifically evaluate fund flows for O&M, management, and development among 
various levels of government. Assess the needs for O&M and the adequacy of 
current  funds  for  sustainable  management  and  development  of  irrigation. 
Highlight constraints and problems. 
(v)  Examine  capacity  and  staff  issues  affecting  irrigation  management  and 
development at the WUAs, and central, provincial, and district agencies, pinpoint 
the implication for government roles and responsibilities, and determine what 
capacity improvement is needed for effective management. 
(vi)  Review the role of WUAs, particularly their participation in civil works under PISP, 
and develop options and guidelines to expand the role of WUAs in civil works 
using government financing where appropriate. Evaluate the role of WUAs in 
O&M and the management of all irrigation schemes, and recommend measures 
to strengthen this role, including policy changes. 
(vii)  Recommend ways to improve O&M, management, and development of, and fund 
flows  for,  irrigation  through  policy  changes  at—or  greater  coordination  and 
cooperation  among—central,  provincial,  and  district  governments.  Develop 
options for better role-sharing agreements; prepare a standard agreement or 
memorandum of understanding that could be used to improve role sharing. 
(viii)  Review existing estimates and government methodologies projecting the need 
for  new  irrigation  areas  in  Indonesia,  including  demand  growth,  production 
efficiency improvements, and other relevant factors and policies. Assess and 
recommend ways to improve current estimates and methodologies based on 
prevailing conditions and best international practice. The executing agency will 
facilitate consultation with the Department of Agriculture. 
(ix)  Examine and make recommendations on the government’s investment strategy 
(short, medium, and long term) for the irrigation sector. 
(x)  Evaluate available information in Indonesia on the effectiveness of rehabilitation 
versus the development of new schemes, providing a basis for an investment 
strategy. 
(xi)  Review recent practice and lessons learned in developing new schemes and (a) 
assess  the  progress  of  development  in  light  of  the  estimated  need  for  new 
schemes, (b) define the constraints in current development practice, and (c) 
make recommendations to improve such practice.  
(xii)  Define  the  parameters,  including  economics  to  be  considered,  for  the 
development of new irrigation areas and devise preliminary selection criteria for 
establishing new schemes. 
(xiii)  Define the methodology and relevant considerations for an irrigation investment 
strategy and assist the government in framing a draft strategy. The investment 
strategy should be consistent with the work undertaken in the national water 
resources investment planning portion of the TA. 
(xiv)  Arrange a workshop to vet and discuss TA findings and outputs, and prepare 
follow-up actions.  
(xv)  Prepare policies, guidelines, rules, and regulations as required to implement TA 
findings, and develop an action plan for their adoption. 
(xvi)  Disseminate outputs and support implementation of TA recommendations and 
guidelines on a pilot or permanent basis.  
(xvii)  Determine training needs, prepare targeted capacity development activities as 
required, and identify events for participation by government officials.
